flow.context: Rebekah Gonzalez is Business Administrator at Penny Realty — listed on BBB alongside CEO Greg Flaherty and VP/CFO Shayne Flaherty, making her part of the senior leadership trio. Penny Realty manages 500+ properties in San Diego across vacation rentals (missionbeach.com, uses Streamline PMS), long-term PM (pennyrealty.com, uses AppFolio), and real estate sales (coastalpro.com). They run a two-step turnover QC — contracted housekeepers clean, then a dedicated inspector verifies every unit — and recently posted a job for a Vacation Rental Home Inspector citing rapid growth. No named inspection ops platform publicly visible. Sam's strongest connection is SoCal roots (grew up in LA, surfs) and work with other San Diego-area property managers.

opener.label: OPENER
opener.say: Hey Rebekah — I work with a few property managers down in the San Diego market, actually grew up not too far away in LA. It's Sam Parks with RapidEye. Have you heard my name tossed around at all?
opener.note: Feet up on the desk energy. Don't rush. Sound like you're calling someone you were meaning to get to. Pause after the question and let her answer.

branches.label: No, I haven't heard of you
Now's not a great time / I'm busy
Who is this? / What's this regarding?

heard_name_no.label: HAVEN'T HEARD OF YOU
heard_name_no.say: Ha — guess I'm not as popular as I thought. Well the reason for my call — I've been working with a few other vacation rental managers running a pretty similar setup to you guys, and something keeps coming up that I think might hit home. You've got what — 500-plus properties across vacation and long-term, and your team runs that post-checkout inspection after every clean on the STR side, right?
heard_name_no.note: Transition naturally into the pain. The 500+ number and two-step QC are from their own site and blog — use them to show homework. Pause and let her confirm or correct.

branches.label: How do you know that? / Where'd you get my info?
I'm not really the person for this

heard_name_yes.label: THEY'VE HEARD OF YOU
heard_name_yes.say: Oh nice — well normally we'd be working with someone in your kind of role. What'd you hear?
heard_name_yes.note: Let her talk. Whatever she says, bridge to the pain trigger. If she mentions a colleague by name, write it down.

branches.label: Someone mentioned you but can't remember details

bad_timing.label: BAD TIMING
bad_timing.say: Totally hear you — would it be a terrible idea if I tried you again tomorrow, maybe same time?
bad_timing.note: Don't push. Be easy. Lock in a specific callback time if possible.

branches.label: Sure, try me tomorrow / gives a time

book_callback.label: LOCK IN CALLBACK
book_callback.say: Perfect — I've got tomorrow pulled up. Would morning or afternoon work better for you? I'll keep it super quick.
book_callback.note: Get a specific time. Write it down. Call back exactly when you said you would — reliability builds trust.

explain_context.label: EXPLAIN HOW YOU KNOW
explain_context.say: Yeah totally fair — no one tipped me off or anything. Your management page on missionbeach.com goes pretty deep into the inspection and turnover process, and I saw on BBB that you're part of the leadership team. I've been reaching out to a few companies in the San Diego vacation rental space and Penny Realty kept coming up as one of the more dialed-in operators. That's actually why I called — you guys clearly take the inspection piece seriously.
explain_context.note: Be transparent. She'll respect honesty. This also positions Penny Realty positively — flattery through specificity, not generic compliments.

branches.label: Okay, go on / what's this about then
I'm not the right person for this

permission_fallback.label: PERMISSION FALLBACK
permission_fallback.say: Yeah totally — it is a cold call, I'll be upfront about that. Can I get 30 seconds to tell you why I reached out? And you can totally hang up on me if it's not a fit.
permission_fallback.note: Disarm with honesty. The 30-second ask is low commitment. Smile through this — don't sound defeated.

branches.label: Fine, go ahead / you've got 30 seconds

permission_rejected.label: PERMISSION REJECTED
permission_rejected.say: Shoot, totally my bad. Just so nobody from my team bugs you again — is it that I caught you at a horrible time, or is it that you already know what we do and this just isn't interesting?
permission_rejected.note: This split question often reopens the door. If it's timing, you get a callback. If it's disinterest, you learn why.

branches.label: Just not interested / please don't call

right_person_check.label: CHECK IF RIGHT PERSON
right_person_check.say: Totally makes sense — and I don't want to waste your time if this isn't your wheelhouse. At Penny Realty, who'd typically own the inspection and turnover workflow on the vacation rental side? Would that be someone like Hunter or Cole, or is there someone else who runs that piece?
right_person_check.note: Drop Hunter Curtis and Cole Holderman's names naturally — they're the Vacation Rental Managers. If she names Mario Jimenez (Operations Manager), that's a great referral too. Get a name and ask how to reach them.

branches.label: Actually, that does touch my role / I'm involved
I don't know / not sure who handles that

pain_trigger.label: PAIN TRIGGER
pain_trigger.say: So here's what I keep hearing from managers running a similar setup — you've got contracted housekeepers doing the turn, then your inspector goes through after every clean checking for damage, wear, missing items. Problem is, when you're running hundreds of turnovers — especially in peak summer season in Mission Beach — stuff slips through. Inspector's moving fast, maybe they miss a scuff behind a door or a stain on a couch that wasn't there yesterday. Then a guest checks in and flags it, or worse — an owner sees it on their next visit and now it's a whole conversation about who's responsible and when it happened. I saw you guys just rolled out that Homeowner Protection Program with the million-dollar coverage — which is smart — but even with that, you still need the documentation to actually back up a claim. Does any of that sound familiar, or is your team pretty much catching everything?
pain_trigger.note: PAUSE after this. Do not fill the silence. The HPP reference shows real research. The question at the end gives her an out that actually opens the door — nobody catches everything.

branches.label: Yeah, that resonates / we deal with that
We're actually pretty good on that front
That's interesting — what do you do about it?
I'm not sure, I don't handle that directly

warm_discovery.label: THEY'RE WARM — ASK QUESTIONS
warm_discovery.say: Yeah, I hear that a lot. So I'm curious — what does that inspection step actually look like for you guys right now? Is your inspector working off a checklist in Streamline, or is it more of a manual walkthrough with photos?
warm_discovery.note: STOP PITCHING. You're in discovery. Mentioning Streamline (their confirmed vacation rental PMS) shows you know their stack. Listen for: what tool they use, how photos are handled, who reviews them, what falls through cracks.

branches.label: It's pretty manual / we're still figuring it out
We use Breezeway / Properly / another ops tool

discovery_dig_deeper.label: DIG DEEPER ON PROCESS
discovery_dig_deeper.say: Got it. And when your inspector flags something — like damage or a maintenance issue — how does that flow? Does it go straight to your in-house maintenance team as a work order, or is someone reviewing and triaging first?
discovery_dig_deeper.note: You're mapping their workflow. The more detail you get, the better you can position RapidEye. They have a 24/7 in-house maintenance team — reference that if she mentions it. Listen for bottlenecks and manual steps.

branches.label: Explains the flow / reveals pain points
It's ad hoc / depends on the person

discovery_pain_expand.label: EXPAND ON MANUAL PAIN
discovery_pain_expand.say: Yeah, that's exactly what I'm hearing from other teams your size. Especially with the growth you guys are going through — I saw you're actually hiring another inspector right now. When you're scaling the team and the portfolio at the same time, that manual process is usually where things start breaking first. What's been the biggest headache with it?
discovery_pain_expand.note: The hiring signal (job post for Vacation Rental Home Inspector citing 'rapid growth') is powerful — shows you know they're actively scaling. Let her vent. Don't interrupt.

branches.label: It's manageable for now / working on it

discovery_current_tool.label: THEY HAVE AN OPS TOOL
discovery_current_tool.say: Oh nice — how's that been working for you? Are you getting what you need out of it, or are there gaps?
discovery_current_tool.note: Don't bash their tool. Listen for what it doesn't do. RapidEye's differentiator is AI analysis of existing photos — most ops tools collect and organize but don't actually analyze what's in the images.

branches.label: It's fine but has gaps / not perfect

solution_statement.label: ONE-SENTENCE SOLUTION
solution_statement.say: So what we built — RapidEye plugs into the photos and videos your team's already taking during turnovers and uses AI to automatically flag damage, missing items, staging issues. No workflow change for your inspectors or cleaners — it just catches the stuff that gets missed when someone's moving fast through a hundred turns a month.
solution_statement.note: One concept, then the 'no workflow change' reassurance. Don't go deeper unless she asks. Pause and let her react.

branches.label: We're not looking for anything new right now

cta_meeting.label: LOW-FRICTION CTA
cta_meeting.say: I'd love to show you what it actually looks like rather than try to explain it over a cold call. Would you be open to taking a look sometime this week — even just 15 minutes? I can walk you through what a couple other San Diego managers are doing with their turnover photos. Worst case you steal some ideas and we part as friends.
cta_meeting.note: Offer of value: competitive intel from other SD vacation rental operators. 'This week' creates urgency without pressure. If she defers to someone else, pivot to referral.

branches.label: You'd need to talk to someone else on our team
We don't have budget for new tools

handle_cost_question.label: HANDLE COST QUESTION
handle_cost_question.say: Honestly it depends on portfolio size and how you're set up — I'd be doing you a disservice throwing out a number without understanding your workflow first. That's actually why I'd love to do a quick walkthrough — I can show you what it looks like on your kind of setup and give you real numbers. Would you be open to 15 minutes this week?
handle_cost_question.note: Never quote price on a cold call. Bridge to meeting. 'Doing you a disservice' positions you as consultative, not evasive.

deflect_price_again.label: DEFLECT PRICE AGAIN
deflect_price_again.say: I hear you — I don't want to waste your time either. For a portfolio your size, we're talking about way less than the cost of one missed damage claim. But honestly the better question is whether it even makes sense for how your team works — that's what I'd figure out in 15 minutes. Fair enough?
deflect_price_again.note: Anchor to the cost of one missed damage claim — for San Diego beach vacation rentals, that's easily hundreds to thousands of dollars. Then redirect to meeting.

branches.label: We just don't have budget right now

objection_not_interested.label: OBJECTION — NOT INTERESTED
objection_not_interested.say: Totally get it. I should've assumed you'd be all set — otherwise you probably would've reached out to us. Just so no one from my team cold calls you again — is it that inspection quality just isn't a focus right now, or is it more that you hate cold calls and I caught you at a bad time?
objection_not_interested.note: Agree first, then split. One option reopens (bad timing), the other gives you intel (not a focus). Either way you learn something. Don't sound hurt.

branches.label: Bad timing / it's the cold call thing
Not a priority / not focused on this
We're happy with what we have

objection_have_process.label: OBJECTION — HAVE A PROCESS
objection_have_process.say: That makes total sense — with 500-plus properties across vacation and long-term, you'd have to have something dialed in, otherwise things would fall apart. Just curious — is it that you're fully covered and happy with how it's working, or is it more that switching anything right now would be a headache you don't need?
objection_have_process.note: Validate their scale. The split separates 'happy' (harder) from 'switching pain' (easier — RapidEye layers on top with no workflow change, so you're not asking them to switch anything).

branches.label: We're happy / it works for us
Switching would be a pain / too much going on

objection_no_budget.label: OBJECTION — NO BUDGET
objection_no_budget.say: Totally get it. Nowadays it's harder to keep a tool, let alone buy something new — especially heading into peak season when every dollar's already spoken for. Just so I know — is it that budget for this cycle is completely locked, or is it more that anything new has to go through Greg and Shayne and it's a whole approval process?
objection_no_budget.note: Naming Greg (CEO) and Shayne (VP/CFO) shows you know the decision structure. If budget is real, sell the test drive for later. If it's approval chain, offer to help build the case.

branches.label: Budget is locked / no room right now
Has to go through leadership / it's a process
Actually let me think about it

sell_test_drive_approval.label: TEST DRIVE — HELP WITH APPROVAL
sell_test_drive_approval.say: Totally hear you. That's actually where a quick look might help — if you see it and it clicks, I can put together a one-pager specific to Penny Realty that you could forward up. Makes the internal conversation a lot easier than trying to explain something you heard about on a cold call. Would 15 minutes be worth it just to see if it's even worth bringing up?
sell_test_drive_approval.note: You're offering to do the work for her. A tailored one-pager for Greg and Shayne makes her look good internally if she brings it forward. Low risk for her.

branches.label: Send me something first and I'll decide

sell_test_drive.label: SELL THE TEST DRIVE
sell_test_drive.say: Totally respect that. You're probably not buying anything off a cold call, and I wouldn't expect you to. But when budget does free up or this comes back around — the people who move fastest are the ones who already know what's first on their list. Would you be open to just taking a look? Not a commitment to anything — just so you know what's out there. If nothing else, I can show you what a couple other San Diego PM companies are doing with their turnover documentation. Worst case you steal some ideas.
sell_test_drive.note: Future-value pitch. You're not asking for a purchase, you're asking for awareness. The competitive intel angle is genuinely valuable — she can benchmark Penny Realty's process against peers.

offer_of_value.label: OFFER OF VALUE
offer_of_value.say: Totally fair. One thing I will say — we've been working with a bunch of PM companies in the vacation rental space, and the ones running that same two-step clean-then-inspect model like you guys are doing some really interesting stuff with photo documentation that I think would be worth seeing. Even if RapidEye's never a fit, I could walk you through what's working for them in 15 minutes. No pitch — just patterns we're seeing across the market. Would that be worth a quick look?
offer_of_value.note: Pure value offer. Position as industry intel, not a sales pitch. Their two-step QC is specific enough that she knows you understand their operation.

branches.label: Send me an email about it

referral_ask_general.label: REFERRAL — GENERAL ASK
referral_ask_general.say: No worries at all. What level of person typically handles the inspection and turnover operations on the vacation rental side? Is that more of a manager role, or does it sit with the ops team?
referral_ask_general.note: Ask about the role and level first, then get the name. Feels less intrusive and gives better intel. She might say operations manager (Mario Jimenez) or vacation rental manager (Hunter/Cole).

referral_suggest_names.label: SUGGEST NAMES FROM RESEARCH
referral_suggest_names.say: Totally get it. I've seen a few names on your team — would someone like Hunter Curtis or Cole Holderman be the right person? Or maybe Mario Jimenez on the ops side?
referral_suggest_names.note: Drop all three names naturally. She'll confirm or correct. Even a 'yeah try Hunter' is a huge win. Write down whoever she points to.

branches.label: Confirms a name / points to someone
I'm not sure / can't really say

referral_get_name.label: GET THE REFERRAL
referral_get_name.say: Perfect — would you mind if I mentioned you pointed me their way? And what's the best way to reach them — is there a direct line, or should I call the main office number?
referral_get_name.note: Get permission to use her name. Get contact info. If she offers to make an intro, that's gold — accept immediately. Write down everything.

branches.label: Sure, mention me / gives contact info
Just call the main line and ask for them
I'll pass your info along to them

send_email_for_referral.label: EMAIL FOR REFERRAL PASS-ALONG
send_email_for_referral.say: That'd be great — I'll put together something quick and specific so it's actually useful when you pass it along. What's the best email for you, is it a coastalpro address?
send_email_for_referral.note: She's offering to forward — make it easy. Send something tailored to the referral target, not a generic deck. Include context like 'Rebekah suggested I reach out.'

book_meeting.label: BOOK THE MEETING
book_meeting.say: Awesome. I've got next week pulled up — would Tuesday or Wednesday work better for you? I'm thinking mid-morning, like 10 or 10:30 your time.
book_meeting.note: Two day options, one specific time. Lock it in now. Don't say 'I'll send a link' — pick the time on the phone. Send the calendar invite while still talking.

branches.label: Let me check my calendar and get back to you

book_meeting_future.label: BOOK FUTURE MEETING
book_meeting_future.say: No rush at all. How about the week after — would something like Thursday or Friday work? I'll send a quick invite so it's on the books, and if anything changes we can always move it.
book_meeting_future.note: Push to a specific date even if further out. A calendar hold is way better than a vague 'let's connect sometime.'

branches.label: Just email me and we'll figure it out

meeting_booked.label: MEETING CONFIRMED
meeting_booked.say: Locked in. I'll shoot over a calendar invite right now — it'll come from sam@rapideye.ai. I'll keep it tight, 15 minutes, and I'll have some stuff pulled together specific to your setup. Really appreciate you taking my call, Rebekah.
meeting_booked.note: STOP SELLING. Confirm details, send the invite immediately, and get off the phone. Don't give her a reason to reconsider. Log the meeting in CRM right after hanging up.

send_email.label: SEND ME AN EMAIL
send_email.say: Totally fair. One quick question before I do — what would be most relevant to include? I don't want to send you the same generic deck everyone gets. Should I focus more on the inspection documentation side, or the damage detection piece, or something else entirely?
send_email.note: Always ask what to include. Gives you intel on priorities and makes your email stand out. Get her email address.

branches.label: Tells you what to focus on
Just send the overview / whatever you've got

confirm_email_address.label: CONFIRM EMAIL
confirm_email_address.say: Got it — I'll put that together today. What's the best email for you? Is it your coastalpro address or a different one?
confirm_email_address.note: coastalpro.com is their vacation rental email domain (greg@coastalpro.com confirmed for CEO). Suggesting it shows familiarity without being creepy. Write down whatever she gives.

branches.label: Use the general inbox / main line

email_confirmed_exit.label: EMAIL CONFIRMED — EXIT
email_confirmed_exit.say: Perfect — you'll have it by end of day. I'll include a couple time options in case anything catches your eye and you want to take a closer look. Appreciate your time, Rebekah.
email_confirmed_exit.note: Send within 2 hours, not end of day — underpromise, overdeliver. Include a specific time suggestion like 'Would Thursday at 10am PT work for a quick 15-min walkthrough?' Follow up by phone in 3 days if no reply.

graceful_exit.label: GRACEFUL EXIT
graceful_exit.say: Totally understand. If anything changes on your end, I'm easy to find — Sam Parks, RapidEye. Appreciate your time, Rebekah.
graceful_exit.note: Don't burn the bridge. Stay warm. You can try again in 3-4 weeks with a different angle or reach out to Hunter, Cole, or Mario directly.

graceful_exit_referral.label: EXIT WITH REFERRAL
graceful_exit_referral.say: Really appreciate that, Rebekah. I'll put something together specific to them so it actually lands. Thanks for pointing me in the right direction — have a good one.
graceful_exit_referral.note: Immediately log the referral name, contact info, and that Rebekah directed you. Use this in your opener: 'Rebekah Gonzalez pointed me your way.' Call the referral within 24 hours while it's fresh.

graceful_exit_with_email.label: EXIT — OFFER EMAIL ANYWAY
graceful_exit_with_email.say: No worries at all. Tell you what — I'll shoot over a quick email with what we're doing for some other San Diego vacation rental managers. If it lands on the right desk, great. If not, no harm done. What's the best email for that?
graceful_exit_with_email.note: Even if she can't name a person, a forwarded email from Rebekah to the right person is still a warm intro. Take whatever she gives you.

branches.label: Just use the website / no email

gatekeeper.label: GATEKEEPER
gatekeeper.say: Hey — could you get me through to Rebekah? It's Sam.
gatekeeper.note: Nothing else. Don't explain, don't pitch, don't give your company name. First name basis only. Sound like you know her. If they ask 'Rebekah who?' say 'Rebekah Gonzalez.'

gatekeeper_context.label: GATEKEEPER — ADD CONTEXT
gatekeeper_context.say: Yeah — I work with a few other property managers in San Diego. Would you mind letting her know it's Sam Parks?
gatekeeper_context.note: Still no company name or pitch. 'Property managers in San Diego' signals relevance without triggering sales-call filter. End with a question so you stay in control.

branches.label: What company? / Can I tell her what it's regarding?

gatekeeper_social_proof.label: GATEKEEPER — SOCIAL PROOF
gatekeeper_social_proof.say: Sure — it's RapidEye. We help a couple other property management companies with their inspection workflows. I sent her a note — would you mind giving her a heads up that I'm on the line?
gatekeeper_social_proof.note: Now give company name. 'Sent her a note' implies prior contact. End with redirect question. If they push back further, don't argue — ask for a good time to call back.

gatekeeper_unavailable.label: GATEKEEPER — NOT AVAILABLE
gatekeeper_unavailable.say: No worries — when's the best time to catch her? I want to make sure I'm not calling at the worst possible moment again.
gatekeeper_unavailable.note: Get a specific time. 'Again' creates familiarity even if it's your first attempt. Write down whatever they say. If they offer voicemail, take it but don't count on a callback.

branches.label: I can transfer you to voicemail

gatekeeper_leave_message.label: LEAVE MESSAGE
gatekeeper_leave_message.say: That'd be great. Just let her know Sam Parks called — she can reach me at my direct line. I'll try her again at the time you mentioned. Appreciate your help.
gatekeeper_leave_message.note: Keep it simple: name, that you'll call back, nothing else. Don't pitch in the voicemail. Goal is name recognition so the next call isn't fully cold. Log the callback time immediately.
